title: Eosinophilic Esophagitis Endoscopic Reference Score (EREFS)
description: Assesses severity of endoscopic findings in patients with eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) using standardized scoring of five major endoscopic features: edema, rings, exudates, furrows, and strictures.

parameters.name: edema
parameters.description: Edema (loss of normal vascular markings; pallor or decreased transparency)

parameters.name: furrows
parameters.description: Furrows (vertical lines or creases along the esophageal wall)

parameters.name: strictures
parameters.description: Strictures (fixed narrowings requiring small-caliber scope or causing resistance)

result.name: erefs_score
result.description: Total EREFS score assessing EoE endoscopic severity

ranges.interpretation: No endoscopic evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis. Consider histologic assessment as endoscopic findings may be absent in early or treated disease. Normal endoscopy does not exclude EoE diagnosis.
Mild endoscopic evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis. Consider correlation with histologic findings and clinical symptoms. Monitor response to treatment and reassess endoscopically.
Moderate endoscopic evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis. Multiple features present suggest established disease. Correlate with histology and consider appropriate anti-inflammatory treatment.

Severe endoscopic evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis. Multiple severe features indicate advanced disease with potential complications. Consider aggressive treatment and close monitoring for stricture formation.

references: Hirano I, Moy N, Heckman MG, Thomas CS, Gonsalves N, Achem SR. Endoscopic assessment of the oesophageal features of eosinophilic oesophagitis: validation of a novel classification and grading system. Gut. 2013 Apr;62(4):489-95. doi: 10.1136/gutjnl-2011-301817.

formula: Total EREFS Score = Edema (0-1) + Rings (0-3) + Exudates (0-2) + Furrows (0-1) + Strictures (0-1)
notes: Score ranges from 0-9 points based on endoscopic findings
Higher scores indicate more severe endoscopic disease
Recommended to use segment with worst (highest) score
Should be used in conjunction with histologic assessment
EREFS helps standardize endoscopic assessment of EoE
Useful for tracking disease progression and treatment response
12-21% of patients may be misclassified regarding therapeutic response
Normal endoscopy (score 0) does not exclude EoE diagnosis
Interobserver agreement is generally good for most features
May not capture all endoscopic abnormalities in EoE
